docs.lead_paragraph: Pregnancy has long been assumed to be a time of expectant joy, at least for women whose pregnancies are planned and who look forward to motherhood. And indeed, it is a happy time for most. But not all. A significant minority -- 10 to 20 percent, depending on who is counting -- suffer moderate to severe depression during pregnancy, which translates to 80,000 women a year in the United States. All too often the problem goes unrecognized by the women and their doctors.

headline.main: The Dilemma of Depression for Mothers-to-Be

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses depression during pregnancy and dilemma facing mothers-to-be and their doctors as to whether antidepressants are worth possible risk to developing baby; two studies on antidepressants and their potential impact on babies described; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Pregnant women are often reluctant to take antidepressants even if their doctors will prescribe them.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Nassau county executive, Thomas Suozzi, is intent on establishing himself in the middle ground on the abortion debate. He announced last May that the county would spend $1 million a year for three years to prevent unintended pregnancies, to promote adoption and to help pregnant women and young mothers find housing and counseling. Last week he revealed who had won the first grants. As promised, the agencies span the great abortion gap, from Planned Parenthood in Hempstead to the Life Center of Long Island, a private Massapequa nonprofit that professes to be doing God's work in ''saving babies, saving souls.''
docs.snippet: Thomas Suozzi's attempts to establish himself in the middle ground on the abortion debate look a lot like old politics.

docs.lead_paragraph: It has long been something of a quirk in the grim universe of diabetes: a small number of pregnant women would become temporarily diabetic. With proper care, the consequences were often thought to be mild. The babies were usually healthy. And the condition would vanish after the delivery, like a cough or a headache. But, not unlike the wider expansion of diabetes, this disorder is now growing, and indications are that it is growing fast. In New York, so-called gestational diabetes has risen by nearly 50 percent in about 10 years.

headline.main: Diabetes Is Seen As a Rising Risk In Mothers-to-Be

docs.abstract: Gestational diabetes, temporary form of diabetes that occurs in some pregnant women, has risen by nearly 50 percent in New York in about 10 years; there is broader recognition that arrival of condition is significant and its impact can be grave: not only does it identify those women at high risk to develop permanent diabetes, but it may contribute to their babies eventually getting diabetes as well; health care officials worry that insufficient attention is being paid to rising number of cases, apparently being propelled by genetically susceptible women entering pregnancy too fat; graph; photo (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Harry Whittington tried to calm the furor yesterday, but we must not let him. Leaving the hospital, he expressed regret for Dick Cheney's troubles over what he considered a simple hunting accident at a friend's ranch. But it was so much more. It was a violation of the public's right to know. Apologists for Dick Cheney argue that the public was informed of the accident, but it took 20 hours -- almost an entire news cycle! The Sunday morning talk shows, deprived of what was rightfully their story, were tragically forced to discuss the National Security Agency and Michelle Kwan's injured groin.

headline.main: The Inalienable Right to Hot Copy

docs.abstract: John Tierney satirical Op-Ed column on media's outrage over how and when White House released news that Vice Pres Dick Cheney had accidentally shot and wounded his hunting partner, Harry Whittington (M)
docs.snippet: Harry Whittington tried to calm the furor Friday, but we must not let him.

docs.lead_paragraph: The abortion-inducing drug RU-486 will probably become available in Australia after a vote yesterday in the House of Representatives. The vote removed the authority to ban the drug from the minister of health, Tony Abbott, who is conservative, Catholic, and opposed to abortion. He had argued against the legislation, saying that abortion was no different from the murder of a pregnant woman's baby.

headline.main: Australia Paves Way for Abortion Drug

docs.snippet: The abortion-inducing drug RU-486 will probably become available in Australia after a vote yesterday in the House of Representatives.     The vote removed the authority to ban the drug from the minister of health, Tony Abbott, who is conservative,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal immigration officials said yesterday that they would investigate allegations that their officers mistreated a pregnant Chinese woman who miscarried twins on Feb. 7 after she was taken from Philadelphia to Kennedy International Airport to be deported. Dean Boyd, a spokesman for Immigration and Customs Enforcement, called the accusations, which spurred protest rallies in two cities yesterday, ''categorically false.'' But ''as a matter of protocol,'' he said, they have been referred to the agency's Office of Professional Responsibility. Mr. Boyd said that immigration officers learned that the woman, Zhenxing Jiang, 32, was pregnant only when she reported to them that day at 9 a.m., and ''they took special precautions in handling her.'' He said the agency had interviewed the officers and concluded that ''contrary to the claims of her attorney, she was not pushed or bruised,'' ridiculed or denied food. He said that she made no complaints of pain until shortly before her flight, and that an ambulance was called immediately. NINA BERNSTEIN (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Inquiry Into Deportation Of Pregnant Woman

docs.abstract: Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials investigate claims of Zhenxing Jiang, pregnant woman who says that mistreatment by guards escorting her for deportation to Kennedy Airport in New York City caused her to miscarry twins; Agency calls Jiang's claims false; incident causes demonstations in New York and Philadelphia, where she was staying (S)

byline.original: By NINA BERNSTEIN (NYT); Compiled by Joseph P. Fried

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush, who acted on his first full day in office five years ago to deny federal aid to overseas groups that help women obtain abortions, is for the first time proposing sharp cuts in financing for international family planning programs that the White House had described as one of the best ways to prevent abortion. Since 2001, the administration had adhered to Mr. Bush's commitment to maintain the financing of such programs at $425 million, the same level as in the last year of the Clinton administration.

headline.main: U.S. Cuts Funds for Family Planning Overseas, Stirring Opposition

docs.snippet: Opponents of the cuts say the reductions would increase unintended pregnancies and abortions among the world's poorest women.
